questions.question_text: Which of the following key project elements is used to organize deliverables into manageable pieces to ensure the proper steps are executed and to achieve the project's core objectives?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A - A Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) is a key project management tool used to organize deliverables into manageable pieces or work packages. It breaks down the project into smaller, more manageable components, which helps in planning, executing, and monitoring the project effectively. By decomposing the project into smaller tasks, the WBS ensures that the proper steps are executed, and it contributes to achieving the project's core objectives. It provides a visual representation of the project's scope and hierarchy of tasks, making it easier to allocate resources, track progress, and manage the project as a whole.

questions.question_text: After a meeting, a team member recaps all of the topics that worked well, worked relatively well, and did not work at all. The expectation is for upcoming project work to make better progress and achieve targets. Which of the following combinations of tactics is being used?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The answer is C. Status meeting, follow-ups.

A status meeting is a meeting that is held to review the progress of a project. The meeting typically includes a discussion of the tasks that have been completed, the tasks that are in progress, and the tasks that are yet to be completed. The meeting also includes a discussion of any issues or challenges that the project is facing.

Follow-ups are actions that are taken after a meeting to ensure that the decisions made in the meeting are implemented. Follow-ups can include sending out meeting notes, assigning tasks, or tracking progress.

The term "follow-ups" indicates that the team is planning to take specific actions to address the issues that didn't work well and to build on the successes. Follow-ups are actions taken after a meeting to ensure that decisions are implemented, issues are resolved, and progress is made. This approach reflects a proactive effort to improve project work and achieve targets.

Hence, the combination of a "status meeting" and "follow-ups" best describes the tactics being used in this scenario.
